[SYNTAX]: Awkward phrasing in "Hebrew is one example among many of a language outliving for purposes of ritual its use in ordinary speech."
[STRUCTURE]: Repetitive sentence structure in "He was not one of those learned men, of whom there are many examples--a recent and conspicuous instance was the late Lord Acton--whose minds are so choked..."
[PUNCTUATION]: Misuse of em dash in "Hebrew is one example among many of a language outliving for purposes of ritual its use in ordinary speech."

[TRANSITION]: Abrupt shift from the foreword's conclusion to Chapter I's opening without connecting ideas.
[LOGIC]: Disjointed flow between historical examples of ritual languages (Roman, Slavonic, etc.) and the broader argument about Hebrew's revival.
[CLARITY]: Unclear linkage between the discussion of Germanism's "special election" and the Jewish claim of chosenness.
